metadata.case_name: Owner of Premises No. 10/3, Swarnamoyee Road v. Howrah Municipality

facts.text: The appellant is the owner of the premises No. 10/3, Swarnamoyee Road, Howrah.
The appellant encroached upon an area of 57 x 3 of the road-side land of the Howrah Municipality to which the provisions of the Calcutta Municipal Act, 1923 have been extended.
A notice was served on the appellant to remove the encroachment, the terms of which required removal within thirty days from the date of service.
The appellant failed to carry out the terms of the notice within the specified time.
Prosecution instituted before the Municipal Magistrate, Second Class, Howrah, in Case No. 1407C/1952.
Municipal Magistrate convicted appellant under s. 488/299 of the Act and sentenced to fine of Rs. 75 on 8th September, 1953.
On appeal, Sessions Judge, Howrah acquitted appellant on ground of limitation under s. 534 of the Act on 14th November, 1953.

Calcutta High Court Division Bench (J. P. Mitter and S. K. Sen JJ.) set aside acquittal in Criminal Revision No. 1113 of 1954 and remanded for re-hearing with opportunity to produce documents on date of complaint institution.
On re-hearing, Additional Sessions Judge confirmed conviction and sentence, dismissed appeal.
Single Judge P.N. Mukherjee J. in revision on 2nd February, 1955, affirmed findings on merits, altered conviction to s. 488/300, reduced sentence to Rs. 50.
The offending structure was a compound wall and not something which was a part and parcel of the main building.
Complaint was instituted within the prescribed period of limitation under s. 534, as shown by official documents proved on remand.
Notice headed under s. 299 but substance required removal of encroachment caused by compound wall measuring 57-0 x 3-0 upon Swarnamoyee Road.

legal_issues.text: Whether the alteration of conviction from s. 488/299 to s. 488/300 of the Calcutta Municipal Act, 1923 was legal without prejudice to the appellant.
Whether the notice served under s. 299 was a lawful requisition within the meaning of s. 488(1)(c) for an offence under s. 300.
Whether the prosecution was barred by limitation under s. 534 of the Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Alteration of conviction from s. 299 to s. 300 read with s. 488 was not possible in law, as suggested by Chief Justice in certificate.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 299, s. 300, s. 488 Calcutta Municipal Act, 1923

petitioner_arguments.text: Notice headed under s. 299 was not lawfully given for offence under s. 300, as compound wall unattached to building falls under s. 300, making requisition under s. 488(1)(c) invalid.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 488(1)(c), s. 299, s. 300 Calcutta Municipal Act, 1923

petitioner_arguments.text: Prosecution launched beyond three months limitation under s. 534.
Substantial prejudice caused by alteration, as under s. 299 might entitle to compensation.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant encroached on municipal land with compound wall, failed to remove after notice; conviction proper.
Complaint instituted in time, as per official documents.

court_reasoning.text: Alteration from s. 299 to s. 300 r/w s. 488 was not alteration in substance but to section more properly applicable to facts found; no illegality citing Begu v. King-Emperor and ss. 236, 237 CrPC principles.
court_reasoning.key_observation: A man may be convicted of an offence, although there has been no charge in respect of it, if the evidence is such as to establish a charge that might have been made.

court_reasoning.text: Substance and not form of notice matters; notice clearly required removal of encroachment by compound wall, appellant aware and failed to comply.
court_reasoning.key_observation: It is the substance and not the form of the notice that has to be regarded.

court_reasoning.text: No prejudice to appellant in trial; fine reduced; any compensation claim irrelevant to criminal proceedings.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The prejudice must have reference to any irregularity in the trial of the case.

court_reasoning.text: Additional evidence shows complaint lodged in time.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The additional evidence placed before the Court puts the matter beyond all reasonable doubt that the complaint had been lodged in time.

holdings.text: Alteration of conviction from s. 488/299 to s. 488/300 valid as facts remained the same and evidence supported it.
Notice was lawful requisition under s. 488(1)(c) r/w s. 300 despite heading under s. 299.

precedents_cited.relevance: Authorizes conviction under different section if evidence supports it, even without specific charge, applying ss. 236, 237 CrPC.

statutes_cited.name: Calcutta Municipal Act, 1923
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs offences for encroachment by projections/buildings (s.299), walls etc. not part of building (s.300), punishment for non-compliance with notice (s.488(1)(c)); limitation (s.534); magistrate (s.531).

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Permits alteration of conviction to offence made out by evidence.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for certificate of fitness for appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: The appeal is dismissed. The conviction under s. 488/300 read with the Calcutta Municipal Act, 1923 and sentence of fine Rs. 50 imposed by the High Court is upheld. No merit in contentions on alteration of section, validity of notice, prejudice or limitation.

key_quotes.text: "A man may be convicted of an offence, although there has been no charge in respect of it, if the evidence is such as to establish a charge that might have been made."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle justifying alteration of conviction citing Privy Council.

key_quotes.text: "It is the substance and not the form of the notice that has to be regarded."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects argument that heading of notice invalidates it for different section.

key_quotes.text: "In view of these considerations, it must be held that there is no merit in this appeal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
